title: 108_s1582
content: The Act titled "Valles Caldera Preservation Act of 2004" includes amendments to the Valles Caldera Preservation Act. The Valles Caldera Preservation Act of 2004 includes amendments related to the acquisition of outstanding mineral interests by the Secretary on a willing seller basis. The Valles Caldera Preservation Act of 2004 includes amendments allowing the Secretary to acquire outstanding mineral interests with available funds if negotiations fail within 60 days. The Secretary will acquire interests with available funds if negotiations fail within 60 days of the enactment of the Valles Caldera Preservation Act of 2004. Any difference in compensation will be paid from a permanent judgment appropriation. The Secretary will acquire interests with available funds if negotiations fail within 60 days of the enactment of the Valles Caldera Preservation Act of 2004. Any difference in compensation will be paid from a permanent judgment appropriation under section 1304 of title 31, United States Code. The Trust shall determine obligations and expenditures subject to applicable laws. The Valles Caldera Preservation Act amends Section 106(e) to give the Trust authority over obligations and expenditures, and Section 106(g) allows for the solicitation of donations. The Valles Caldera Preservation Act amends Section 106(e) to grant the Trust authority over obligations and expenditures, while Section 106(g) now specifies who can solicit donations. The Valles Caldera Preservation Act amends Section 106(g) to specify who can solicit donations and Section 106(h)(1) regarding the use of proceeds from claims or settlements after October 27, 1999. The Valles Caldera Preservation Act amends Section 106(g) and Section 106(h)(1) regarding donations and use of proceeds. SEC. 3 establishes the Board of Trustees. Section 107(e) of the Valles Caldera Preservation Act is amended to specify the selection and compensation of trustees. The Valles Caldera Preservation Act is amended to address the selection and compensation of trustees, including the option for the chair to receive compensation at a rate determined by the Board of Trustees. The total compensation cannot exceed the daily equivalent of the annual rate of pay for level IV of the Executive Schedule. The Valles Caldera Preservation Act allows for the chair of the Board of Trustees to receive compensation determined by the Board, not exceeding 25 percent of the annual rate of pay for level IV of the Executive Schedule. SEC. 4. RESOURCE MANAGEMENT. Property Disposal Limitations amended under the Valles Caldera Preservation Act to include restrictions on disposal duration and termination. The Valles Caldera Preservation Act was amended to include restrictions on disposal duration and termination for property. Additionally, the disposal of real property does not include the sale of forage, forest products, or renewable resources. The Valles Caldera Preservation Act was amended to include restrictions on disposal duration and termination for property. Exclusions for disposal of real property include forage, forest products, and renewable resources. Amendments were made to Section 108(g) regarding law enforcement and fire management. The Valles Caldera Preservation Act (16 U.S.C. 698v-6(g)) is amended to include provisions for law enforcement and fire management. Amendments were made to Section 108(g) regarding these aspects. The Valles Caldera Preservation Act is amended to include provisions for fire management on the Preserve, with the Secretary developing a plan in consultation with the Trust for fire preparedness, suppression, and emergency rehabilitation services. The Secretary, in consultation with the Trust, will develop a plan for fire preparedness, suppression, and emergency rehabilitation services on the Preserve, consistent with the management program. The plan for fire services on the Preserve must be consistent with the management program and carried out through a cooperative agreement between the Secretary and the Trust. The Secretary shall provide fire services through a cooperative agreement with the Trust, including reimbursable presuppression and nonemergency services. The Secretary may provide presuppression and nonemergency rehabilitation and restoration services for the Trust on a reimbursable basis. The Senate passed the bill on September 15, 2004. Attest: EMILY J. REYNOLDS, Secretary.
